  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours

    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Happy Fourth of July, everyone. This is Russ
  Mitchell filling in for Katie.
 
A record number of Americans are celebrating the
  holiday today away from home. And transportation security is extra tight after
  the thwarted terror attacks in the U.K. Nancy Cordes will look at the security
  – and the celebrations – on the land, at sea and in the sky
  tonight.
 
But extreme weather in some parts of the United States
  is putting barbeques and fireworks on hold. Alabama,
  Mississippi and Tennessee are in a serious drought, and
  rivers are so low barges are having trouble getting through. But Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas have the
  opposite problem: major flooding – and an oil spill is complicating
  matters. Sandra Hughes and Hari Sreenivasan will have these stories tonight.
 
Turning our attention overseas, the investigation
  into the U.K.
  terror plot continues, and our Sheila MacVicar will have the latest details.
 
It was literally a day to celebrate freedom for
  British reporter Alan Johnston – he was released after nearly four
  months in captivity in the Gaza Strip. Johnston, a BBC reporter, said it was
  “fantastic” to be free from the jihadi group called Army of Islam.
  Elizabeth Palmer will have the story.
 
On a lighter note, there’s something fishy
  going on in some of the country’s finest lakes. Sharyn Alfonsi will set
  the record straight.
 
And we’ll leave you tonight with a touching story
  about the healing power of animals. 
 
Have a wonderful holiday,
 




Russ Mitchell
CouricandCo@cbs.com
